item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“RSPRIVATESERVER, post:28, topic:281731”]So the plugins will provide the functions that the scripts will use?

So if I were to write an NPC plugin, it would have functions like spawnNPC()? and then a script writer would be able to spawn his NPC’s using SpawnNPC()?
Or am I totally confused?[/quote]

Yeah, you can think of it like that. We’ve still got a lot to consider though.

item.title: [RuneSource]: Huge scratch server undertaking
item.dc:creator: @_ikram _ikram
item.description:
@_ikram wrote:

[quote=“Pheega, post:26, topic:281731”][quote author=_ikram link=topic=372183.msg2813329#msg2813329 date=1244135128]
To create drivers for specific platforms your best bet is to use a low level programming language like assembler/c/c++ i’m not sure if java is an ideal language to program drivers with.

Good luck.
[/quote]I believe you are not on the same page as us when it comes to the terms “driver” and “platform”. The RuneSource drivers are simply utilities to run the core, it has nothing to do with the operating system. Platforms are simply game worlds, a platform on which content can be added. We aren’t doing any incredibly low-level programming, we just chose those terms because they are appropriate in relation to the core.[/quote]

oh ok i see, i got confused.

Read full topic

Good luck.[/quote]I believe you are not on the same page as us when it comes to the terms “driver” and “platform”. The RuneSource drivers are simply utilities to run the core, it has nothing to do with the operating system. Platforms are simply game worlds, a platform on which content can be added. We aren’t doing any incredibly low-level programming, we just chose those terms because they are appropriate in relation to the core.

We are looking for highly capable programmers to help us create the entire framework that will support the rapid development of the entire community. Currently, the RuneSource framework has come a long way.[/quote]

I must say, this is quite a beautiful WPA. But sorry, Oriole is still greater.

item.title: [RuneSource]: Huge scratch server undertaking
item.dc:creator: @_ikram _ikram
item.description:
@_ikram wrote:

Yeh, your Network driver:
there are easier way’s

/** * Sets up the networking driver. */ public void init() { logger.info("Setting up network driver..."); try { reactor = new Reactor(); running = true; } catch (IOException ex) { logger.log(Level.SEVERE, "Error starting reactor.", ex); } } [br][br][size=1]Posted on: June 03, 2009, 11:56:42 am[/size][hr]I had a similar Platform loader

public static Platform loadPlatform(String name, InetSocketAddress addr) {         Platform platform = null;         try {                     Class<?> clazz = Class.forName(name);                     Constructor<?> constructor = clazz.getConstructor(InetSocketAddress.class);                     platform = (Platform) constructor.newInstance(addr);         } catch(Exception ex) {                 platform = null;         }         return platform;     }  }

Read full topic

What process are you planning to use for the drivers and how are you planning to implement them?[/quote]

You’ll have to PM Pheega about joining. What do you mean exactly about ‘process’ for the drivers? Btw, we already have a NetworkDriver, PlatformDriver and PluginDriver so you can have a look at how those work.

item.title: [RuneSource]: Huge scratch server undertaking
item.dc:creator: @_ikram _ikram
item.description:
@_ikram wrote:

i dont know, i dont think it’s going to work, it just be the way you want it, making a pluggable system.

but for loading plateforms, good idea

public static Platform loadPlatform(String name, InetSocketAddress addr) { Platform platform = null; try { Class<?> clazz = Class.forName(name); Constructor<?> constructor = clazz.getConstructor(InetSocketAddress.class); platform = (Platform) constructor.newInstance(addr); } catch(Exception ex) { platform = null; } return platform; }

Read full topic

item.title: [RuneSource]: Huge scratch server undertaking
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

_ikram:

Reading this again, how are you planning to up the entire system and managing the drivers during runtime.

It’s possible to dynamically load classes at runtime using reflection which is what we already have the beginnings of.

For loading plugins:

Class<?> clazz = Class.forName(name);
plugin = (Plugin) clazz.newInstance();

For loading platforms:

Class<?> clazz = Class.forName(name);
Constructor<?> constructor = clazz.getConstructor(InetSocketAddress.class);
platform = (Platform) constructor.newInstance(addr);

Obviously we’ve still got quite a while until we get the whole, nice pluggable system running but we’ve already got a good start for everything.

Read full topic

item.title: [RuneSource]: Huge scratch server undertaking
item.dc:creator: @Envion Envion
item.description:
@Envion wrote:

[quote=“Pheega, post:10, topic:281731”][quote author=Envion link=topic=372183.msg2810858#msg2810858 date=1243980971]

Only thing I can say is, make a file that handles version updates so that it would be easy to update it from say 317 to 508.

Platforms
Inside the driver system is a driver called the PlatformDriver, which runs and maintains all of the “platforms” inside RuneSource. A platform, in RuneSource, is a world. These worlds are highly flexible - to the point of being able to support different protocols (317, 508, etc.) and through the power of the PlatformDriver, multiple platforms can be run concurrently inside RuneSource.

You’re given the tools. The rest is up to you.
[/quote]Exactly.

@Envion: read the PM reply.[/quote]

Response sent. My apologies for being blind.

Read full topic

Platforms Inside the driver system is a driver called the PlatformDriver, which runs and maintains all of the "platforms" inside RuneSource. A platform, in RuneSource, is a world. These worlds are highly flexible - to the point of being able to support different protocols (317, 508, etc.) and through the power of the PlatformDriver, multiple platforms can be run concurrently inside RuneSource.

item.title: [RuneSource]: Huge scratch server undertaking
item.dc:creator: @Pheega Pheega
item.description:
@Pheega wrote:

[quote=“Envion, post:4, topic:281731”][quote author=Newty link=topic=372183.msg2810107#msg2810107 date=1243950512]
Look’s good, if not somewhat similar to Blakes.

Good luck though.
[/quote]

It is similar to Blake’s because the reactor pattern is the best way to go in terms of concurrency.

He’s coupled it with the facade pattern for the less experienced developers, which is something Blake’s project didn’t do. In his version all the internal wiring was exposed, scaring away even some of the more veteran (if not advanced) developers. It [the facade] provides an API for less experienced programmers to use in their development, allowing them to develop without worrying about “how it works.”[/quote]Your understanding on design patterns/etc. is quite impressive

Read full topic
